abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Sector Project
            for Burkina Faso were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low, the
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the low quality of the final
            engineering design and procurement documents that were
            certified to be ready at approval for the first year's
            activities of the project and that did not address
            adequately the technical approach of road improvement
            envisaged by the project, has led to important delays for
            the project implementation. It would be appropriate to
            ensure technical design studies and bidding documents
            completely validated and approved before declaring them
            ready when considering the project first year's
            investment program. The introduction of the spot improvement
            concept in rehabilitation works on roads with low traffic
            requires careful preparation/advocacy/planning so it can
            work locally. The tendency of road administrations,
            contractors and consultants is to fully rehabilitate the
            concerned roads. For TSP, technical studies did not
            appropriately take this concept into account while designing
            the needed works, and bids came in higher than expected.
            Contractors misunderstood the concept introduced by the
            project of road spot improvements at the start of the
            project. This means that without full ownership of the spot
            improvement rehabilitation concept and capacity to implement
            it, it should not be attempted or should be redefined as a
            classical bridges/culvert/drainage works
            rehabilitation/construction approach. High Intensity
            Labor-based Method (HILM) approach for small scale roads
            should be promoted as a way to provide job opportunities for
            local populations.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Additional Financing for
            Transport Sectoral Project : social and environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This assessment of the Transport
            Sectoral Project of Burkina Faso has as its objectives to:
            identify and assess the impacts on the environment likely to
            be generated by the execution of the work of dirt roads and
            the exploitation of rehabilitated roads; propose and
            evaluate the extent necessary to prevent, limit, offset, or
            repair the negative impacts and maximize positive impacts
            associated with the work, conforming to the strategy within
            the framework of the Transport Sectoral Project. The various
            activities related to the work of rehabilitation of roads
            induce environment impacts on physical, biological and human
            phase of works (road construction) and after work (use of
            roads). Negative impacts of the project include: Impacts and
            measures related to soil; hydrology; vegetation, water,
            landscape, wildlife and flora; public health; traffic
            disruption for road users; and public security.

0.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Financement Additionnel
            de Projet Sectoriel des Transporte : actualisation notice
            d'impact environnemental et social

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Transport Sectoral Project :
            social and environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment highlights
            negative as well as positive impacts that could affect the
            natural and human environment components during preparation,
            implementation, and operation of the Transport Sector
            Project for Burkina Faso. It reports that the most affected
            environmental and social aspects are: air quality due to
            dust dispersion and atmospheric releases; water supply,
            which could result in restricting availability; soils
            affected by erosion and compacting, which lead to land loss;
            degradation and fragmentation of animal habitat; protected
            areas where work is carried out without supervision;
            population directly affected by work which is not
            compensated on time; women, who are generally excluded from
            the consultation and compensation processes, although they
            are affected by the works; a decreased standard of living
            due to disruption of lifestyle or of economic activities;
            and health risks to population because of accidents,
            sexually transmitted diseases, and respiratory diseases.
            Mitigation measures are of two types: those requiring minor
            adjustments to current methods or practices, and those
            requiring in-depth changes in the processes. Measures in the
            first category include: identifying protected areas,
            deciding areas for heavy machinery transport, scheduling
            work, determining water supply potential, managing toxic
            materials and potential contaminants, and equally employing
            women and men. Measures requiring substantial changes
            include: ensuring work area safety, training workers about
            safety, developing better information and consultative
            processes, protecting rivers, rehabilitating construction
            sites once work has finished, and reducing pollutants
            (noise, dust, and landscape).
